utils.visualization.static_plots¶

Source: src\utils\visualization\static_plots.py

Module Overview¶

Static plotting utilities for control system analysis.

Provides comprehensive plotting functions for control system performance, phase portraits, time series analysis, and system identification.

Complete Source Code¶

  1#======================================================================================\\\
  2#====================== src/utils/visualization/static_plots.py =======================\\\
  3#======================================================================================\\\
  4
  5"""
  6Static plotting utilities for control system analysis.
  7
  8Provides comprehensive plotting functions for control system performance,
  9phase portraits, time series analysis, and system identification.
 10"""
 11
 12from __future__ import annotations
 13import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 14import numpy as np
 15from typing import List, Dict, Any, Optional, Tuple
 16
 17class ControlPlotter:
 18    """Static plotting utilities for control system analysis."""
 19
 20    def __init__(self, style: str = 'seaborn-v0_8', figsize: Tuple[float, float] = (12, 8)):
 21        """Initialize plotter with style settings."""
 22        plt.style.use(style)
 23        self.default_figsize = figsize
 24
 25    def plot_time_series(
 26        self,
 27        time: List[float],
 28        data: Dict[str, List[float]],
 29        title: str = "Time Series",
 30        ylabel: str = "Value",
 31        save_path: Optional[str] = None
 32    ) -> plt.Figure:
 33        """Plot multiple time series on the same axes."""
 34        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=self.default_figsize)
 35
 36        for label, values in data.items():
 37            ax.plot(time, values, label=label, linewidth=2)
 38
 39        ax.set_xlabel("Time (s)")
 40        ax.set_ylabel(ylabel)
 41        ax.set_title(title)
 42        ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
 43        ax.legend()
 44
 45        if save_path:
 46            fig.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
 47
 48        return fig
 49
 50    def plot_state_evolution(
 51        self,
 52        time: List[float],
 53        state_history: List[np.ndarray],
 54        state_labels: List[str] = None,
 55        save_path: Optional[str] = None
 56    ) -> plt.Figure:
 57        """Plot evolution of all state variables."""
 58        state_array = np.array(state_history)
 59        n_states = state_array.shape[1]
 60
 61        if state_labels is None:
 62            state_labels = [f"State {i+1}" for i in range(n_states)]
 63
 64        fig, axes = plt.subplots(n_states, 1, figsize=(12, 2*n_states), sharex=True)
 65        if n_states == 1:
 66            axes = [axes]
 67
 68        for i, ax in enumerate(axes):
 69            ax.plot(time, state_array[:, i], linewidth=2, color=f'C{i}')
 70            ax.set_ylabel(state_labels[i])
 71            ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
 72
 73        axes[-1].set_xlabel("Time (s)")
 74        fig.suptitle("State Evolution", fontsize=16)
 75
 76        if save_path:
 77            fig.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
 78
 79        return fig
 80
 81    def plot_phase_portrait(
 82        self,
 83        state_history: List[np.ndarray],
 84        x_idx: int = 0,
 85        y_idx: int = 1,
 86        title: str = "Phase Portrait",
 87        save_path: Optional[str] = None
 88    ) -> plt.Figure:
 89        """Plot phase portrait of two state variables."""
 90        state_array = np.array(state_history)
 91
 92        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=self.default_figsize)
 93
 94        # Plot trajectory
 95        ax.plot(state_array[:, x_idx], state_array[:, y_idx], 'b-', linewidth=2, alpha=0.7)
 96
 97        # Mark start and end points
 98        ax.plot(state_array[0, x_idx], state_array[0, y_idx], 'go', markersize=10, label='Start')
 99        ax.plot(state_array[-1, x_idx], state_array[-1, y_idx], 'ro', markersize=10, label='End')
100
101        # Add direction arrows
102        n_arrows = 10
103        arrow_indices = np.linspace(0, len(state_array)-2, n_arrows, dtype=int)
104        for i in arrow_indices:
105            dx = state_array[i+1, x_idx] - state_array[i, x_idx]
106            dy = state_array[i+1, y_idx] - state_array[i, y_idx]
107            ax.arrow(state_array[i, x_idx], state_array[i, y_idx], dx, dy,
108                    head_width=0.02, head_length=0.02, fc='red', ec='red', alpha=0.6)
109
110        ax.set_xlabel(f"State {x_idx + 1}")
111        ax.set_ylabel(f"State {y_idx + 1}")
112        ax.set_title(title)
113        ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
114        ax.legend()
115
116        if save_path:
117            fig.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
118
119        return fig
120
121    def plot_control_performance(
122        self,
123        time: List[float],
124        control_history: List[float],
125        reference: Optional[List[float]] = None,
126        save_path: Optional[str] = None
127    ) -> plt.Figure:
128        """Plot control input and reference tracking."""
129        fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 1, figsize=self.default_figsize, sharex=True)
130
131        # Control input
132        axes[0].plot(time, control_history, 'b-', linewidth=2, label='Control Input')
133        axes[0].set_ylabel("Control Force (N)")
134        axes[0].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
135        axes[0].legend()
136
137        # Reference tracking (if provided)
138        if reference is not None:
139            axes[1].plot(time, reference, 'r--', linewidth=2, label='Reference')
140            axes[1].set_ylabel("Reference")
141        else:
142            # Plot control effort distribution
143            axes[1].hist(control_history, bins=50, alpha=0.7, edgecolor='black')
144            axes[1].set_ylabel("Frequency")
145            axes[1].set_title("Control Effort Distribution")
146
147        axes[1].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
148        axes[1].legend()
149        axes[1].set_xlabel("Time (s)")
150
151        fig.suptitle("Control Performance Analysis", fontsize=16)
152
153        if save_path:
154            fig.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
155
156        return fig
157
158    def plot_sliding_surface(
159        self,
160        time: List[float],
161        sigma_history: List[float],
162        boundary_layer: Optional[float] = None,
163        save_path: Optional[str] = None
164    ) -> plt.Figure:
165        """Plot sliding surface evolution for SMC analysis."""
166        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=self.default_figsize)
167
168        ax.plot(time, sigma_history, 'b-', linewidth=2, label='Sliding Surface σ')
169
170        # Add boundary layer if specified
171        if boundary_layer is not None:
172            ax.axhline(y=boundary_layer, color='red', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7, label='Boundary Layer')
173            ax.axhline(y=-boundary_layer, color='red', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7)
174            ax.fill_between(time, -boundary_layer, boundary_layer, alpha=0.2, color='yellow')
175
176        ax.axhline(y=0, color='black', linestyle='-', alpha=0.5)
177        ax.set_xlabel("Time (s)")
178        ax.set_ylabel("Sliding Surface Value")
179        ax.set_title("Sliding Surface Evolution")
180        ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
181        ax.legend()
182
183        if save_path:
184            fig.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
185
186        return fig
187
188    def plot_energy_analysis(
189        self,
190        time: List[float],
191        kinetic_energy: List[float],
192        potential_energy: List[float],
193        total_energy: List[float],
194        save_path: Optional[str] = None
195    ) -> plt.Figure:
196        """Plot system energy analysis."""
197        fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 1, figsize=self.default_figsize, sharex=True)
198
199        # Energy components
200        axes[0].plot(time, kinetic_energy, 'b-', linewidth=2, label='Kinetic Energy')
201        axes[0].plot(time, potential_energy, 'r-', linewidth=2, label='Potential Energy')
202        axes[0].plot(time, total_energy, 'k--', linewidth=2, label='Total Energy')
203        axes[0].set_ylabel("Energy (J)")
204        axes[0].set_title("System Energy Components")
205        axes[0].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
206        axes[0].legend()
207
208        # Energy conservation analysis
209        energy_change = np.array(total_energy) - total_energy[0]
210        axes[1].plot(time, energy_change, 'g-', linewidth=2)
211        axes[1].set_xlabel("Time (s)")
212        axes[1].set_ylabel("Energy Change (J)")
213        axes[1].set_title("Energy Conservation Analysis")
214        axes[1].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
215
216        if save_path:
217            fig.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
218
219        return fig
220
221    def plot_performance_comparison(
222        self,
223        data_sets: Dict[str, Dict[str, List[float]]],
224        metric_names: List[str],
225        save_path: Optional[str] = None
226    ) -> plt.Figure:
227        """Plot performance comparison between different controllers."""
228        n_metrics = len(metric_names)
229        fig, axes = plt.subplots(n_metrics, 1, figsize=(12, 3*n_metrics), sharex=True)
230
231        if n_metrics == 1:
232            axes = [axes]
233
234        for i, metric in enumerate(metric_names):
235            for controller_name, controller_data in data_sets.items():
236                if metric in controller_data:
237                    axes[i].plot(controller_data['time'], controller_data[metric],
238                               linewidth=2, label=controller_name)
239
240            axes[i].set_ylabel(metric)
241            axes[i].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
242            axes[i].legend()
243
244        axes[-1].set_xlabel("Time (s)")
245        fig.suptitle("Controller Performance Comparison", fontsize=16)
246
247        if save_path:
248            fig.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
249
250        return fig
251
252class SystemVisualization:
253    """High-level visualization for complete system analysis."""
254
255    def __init__(self):
256        """Initialize system visualization."""
257        self.plotter = ControlPlotter()
258
259    def create_complete_analysis_report(
260        self,
261        simulation_data: Dict[str, Any],
262        output_dir: str = "analysis_plots"
263    ) -> Dict[str, str]:
264        """Generate complete visualization report for system analysis."""
265        import os
266        os.makedirs(output_dir, exist_ok=True)
267
268        saved_plots = {}
269
270        # Extract data
271        time = simulation_data['time']
272        states = simulation_data['states']
273        controls = simulation_data['controls']
274
275        # 1. State evolution
276        fig = self.plotter.plot_state_evolution(time, states)
277        path = os.path.join(output_dir, "state_evolution.png")
278        fig.savefig(path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
279        saved_plots['state_evolution'] = path
280        plt.close(fig)
281
282        # 2. Phase portraits
283        fig = self.plotter.plot_phase_portrait(states, 0, 3)  # Position vs velocity
284        path = os.path.join(output_dir, "phase_portrait.png")
285        fig.savefig(path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
286        saved_plots['phase_portrait'] = path
287        plt.close(fig)
288
289        # 3. Control performance
290        fig = self.plotter.plot_control_performance(time, controls)
291        path = os.path.join(output_dir, "control_performance.png")
292        fig.savefig(path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
293        saved_plots['control_performance'] = path
294        plt.close(fig)
295
296        # 4. Additional plots based on available data
297        if 'sigma' in simulation_data:
298            fig = self.plotter.plot_sliding_surface(time, simulation_data['sigma'])
299            path = os.path.join(output_dir, "sliding_surface.png")
300            fig.savefig(path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
301            saved_plots['sliding_surface'] = path
302            plt.close(fig)
303
304        return saved_plots

Classes¶

ControlPlotter¶

Static plotting utilities for control system analysis.

Source Code¶

  1class ControlPlotter:

 19

 22

 34    def plot_state_evolution(

 65    def plot_phase_portrait(
 66        self,
 67        state_history: List[np.ndarray],
 68        x_idx: int = 0,
 69        y_idx: int = 1,
 70        title: str = "Phase Portrait",
 71        save_path: Optional[str] = None
 72    ) -> plt.Figure:
 73        """Plot phase portrait of two state variables."""
 74        state_array = np.array(state_history)
 75
 76        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=self.default_figsize)
 77
 78        # Plot trajectory
 79        ax.plot(state_array[:, x_idx], state_array[:, y_idx], 'b-', linewidth=2, alpha=0.7)
 80
 81        # Mark start and end points
 82        ax.plot(state_array[0, x_idx], state_array[0, y_idx], 'go', markersize=10, label='Start')
 83        ax.plot(state_array[-1, x_idx], state_array[-1, y_idx], 'ro', markersize=10, label='End')
 84
 85        # Add direction arrows
 86        n_arrows = 10
 87        arrow_indices = np.linspace(0, len(state_array)-2, n_arrows, dtype=int)
 88        for i in arrow_indices:
 89            dx = state_array[i+1, x_idx] - state_array[i, x_idx]
 90            dy = state_array[i+1, y_idx] - state_array[i, y_idx]
 91            ax.arrow(state_array[i, x_idx], state_array[i, y_idx], dx, dy,
 92                    head_width=0.02, head_length=0.02, fc='red', ec='red', alpha=0.6)
 93
 94        ax.set_xlabel(f"State {x_idx + 1}")
 95        ax.set_ylabel(f"State {y_idx + 1}")
 96        ax.set_title(title)
 97        ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
 98        ax.legend()
 99
100        if save_path:
101            fig.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
102
103        return fig
104
105    def plot_control_performance(
106        self,
107        time: List[float],
108        control_history: List[float],
109        reference: Optional[List[float]] = None,
110        save_path: Optional[str] = None
111    ) -> plt.Figure:
112        """Plot control input and reference tracking."""
113        fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 1, figsize=self.default_figsize, sharex=True)
114
115        # Control input
116        axes[0].plot(time, control_history, 'b-', linewidth=2, label='Control Input')
117        axes[0].set_ylabel("Control Force (N)")
118        axes[0].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
119        axes[0].legend()
120
121        # Reference tracking (if provided)
122        if reference is not None:
123            axes[1].plot(time, reference, 'r--', linewidth=2, label='Reference')
124            axes[1].set_ylabel("Reference")
125        else:
126            # Plot control effort distribution
127            axes[1].hist(control_history, bins=50, alpha=0.7, edgecolor='black')
128            axes[1].set_ylabel("Frequency")
129            axes[1].set_title("Control Effort Distribution")
130
131        axes[1].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
132        axes[1].legend()
133        axes[1].set_xlabel("Time (s)")
134
135        fig.suptitle("Control Performance Analysis", fontsize=16)
136
137        if save_path:
138            fig.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
139
140        return fig
141
142    def plot_sliding_surface(
143        self,
144        time: List[float],
145        sigma_history: List[float],
146        boundary_layer: Optional[float] = None,
147        save_path: Optional[str] = None
148    ) -> plt.Figure:
149        """Plot sliding surface evolution for SMC analysis."""
150        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=self.default_figsize)
151
152        ax.plot(time, sigma_history, 'b-', linewidth=2, label='Sliding Surface σ')
153
154        # Add boundary layer if specified
155        if boundary_layer is not None:
156            ax.axhline(y=boundary_layer, color='red', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7, label='Boundary Layer')
157            ax.axhline(y=-boundary_layer, color='red', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7)
158            ax.fill_between(time, -boundary_layer, boundary_layer, alpha=0.2, color='yellow')
159
160        ax.axhline(y=0, color='black', linestyle='-', alpha=0.5)
161        ax.set_xlabel("Time (s)")
162        ax.set_ylabel("Sliding Surface Value")
163        ax.set_title("Sliding Surface Evolution")
164        ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
165        ax.legend()
166
167        if save_path:
168            fig.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
169
170        return fig
171
172    def plot_energy_analysis(
173        self,
174        time: List[float],
175        kinetic_energy: List[float],
176        potential_energy: List[float],
177        total_energy: List[float],
178        save_path: Optional[str] = None
179    ) -> plt.Figure:
180        """Plot system energy analysis."""
181        fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 1, figsize=self.default_figsize, sharex=True)
182
183        # Energy components
184        axes[0].plot(time, kinetic_energy, 'b-', linewidth=2, label='Kinetic Energy')
185        axes[0].plot(time, potential_energy, 'r-', linewidth=2, label='Potential Energy')
186        axes[0].plot(time, total_energy, 'k--', linewidth=2, label='Total Energy')
187        axes[0].set_ylabel("Energy (J)")
188        axes[0].set_title("System Energy Components")
189        axes[0].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
190        axes[0].legend()
191
192        # Energy conservation analysis
193        energy_change = np.array(total_energy) - total_energy[0]
194        axes[1].plot(time, energy_change, 'g-', linewidth=2)
195        axes[1].set_xlabel("Time (s)")
196        axes[1].set_ylabel("Energy Change (J)")
197        axes[1].set_title("Energy Conservation Analysis")
198        axes[1].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
199
200        if save_path:
201            fig.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
202
203        return fig
204
205    def plot_performance_comparison(
206        self,
207        data_sets: Dict[str, Dict[str, List[float]]],
208        metric_names: List[str],
209        save_path: Optional[str] = None
210    ) -> plt.Figure:
211        """Plot performance comparison between different controllers."""
212        n_metrics = len(metric_names)
213        fig, axes = plt.subplots(n_metrics, 1, figsize=(12, 3*n_metrics), sharex=True)
214
215        if n_metrics == 1:
216            axes = [axes]
217
218        for i, metric in enumerate(metric_names):
219            for controller_name, controller_data in data_sets.items():
220                if metric in controller_data:
221                    axes[i].plot(controller_data['time'], controller_data[metric],
222                               linewidth=2, label=controller_name)
223
224            axes[i].set_ylabel(metric)
225            axes[i].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
226            axes[i].legend()
227
228        axes[-1].set_xlabel("Time (s)")
229        fig.suptitle("Controller Performance Comparison", fontsize=16)
230
231        if save_path:
232            fig.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
233
234        return fig

SystemVisualization¶

High-level visualization for complete system analysis.

Source Code¶

 1class SystemVisualization:
 2    """High-level visualization for complete system analysis."""
 3
 4    def __init__(self):
 5        """Initialize system visualization."""
 6        self.plotter = ControlPlotter()
 7
 8    def create_complete_analysis_report(
 9        self,
10        simulation_data: Dict[str, Any],
11        output_dir: str = "analysis_plots"
12    ) -> Dict[str, str]:
13        """Generate complete visualization report for system analysis."""
14        import os
15        os.makedirs(output_dir, exist_ok=True)
16
17        saved_plots = {}
18
19        # Extract data
20        time = simulation_data['time']
21        states = simulation_data['states']
22        controls = simulation_data['controls']
23
24        # 1. State evolution
25        fig = self.plotter.plot_state_evolution(time, states)
26        path = os.path.join(output_dir, "state_evolution.png")
27        fig.savefig(path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
28        saved_plots['state_evolution'] = path
29        plt.close(fig)
30
31        # 2. Phase portraits
32        fig = self.plotter.plot_phase_portrait(states, 0, 3)  # Position vs velocity
33        path = os.path.join(output_dir, "phase_portrait.png")
34        fig.savefig(path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
35        saved_plots['phase_portrait'] = path
36        plt.close(fig)
37
38        # 3. Control performance
39        fig = self.plotter.plot_control_performance(time, controls)
40        path = os.path.join(output_dir, "control_performance.png")
41        fig.savefig(path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
42        saved_plots['control_performance'] = path
43        plt.close(fig)
44
45        # 4. Additional plots based on available data
46        if 'sigma' in simulation_data:
47            fig = self.plotter.plot_sliding_surface(time, simulation_data['sigma'])
48            path = os.path.join(output_dir, "sliding_surface.png")
49            fig.savefig(path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
50            saved_plots['sliding_surface'] = path
51            plt.close(fig)
52
53        return saved_plots

Dependencies¶

This module imports:

  • from __future__ import annotations

  • import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

  • import numpy as np

  • from typing import List, Dict, Any, Optional, Tuple

  • import matplotlib.patches as patches

Architecture Diagram¶

graph TD A[Component] --> B[Subcomponent 1] A --> C[Subcomponent 2] B --> D[Output] C --> D style A fill:#e1f5ff style D fill:#e8f5e9

Usage Examples¶

Example 1: Basic Usage¶

# Basic usage example
from src.utils import Component

component = Component()
result = component.process(data)

Example 2: Advanced Configuration¶

# Advanced configuration
component = Component(
    option1=value1,
    option2=value2
)

Example 3: Integration with Framework¶

# Integration example
from src.simulation import SimulationRunner

runner = SimulationRunner()
runner.use_component(component)

Example 4: Performance Optimization¶

# Performance-optimized usage
component = Component(enable_caching=True)

Example 5: Error Handling¶

# Error handling
try:
    result = component.process(data)
except ComponentError as e:
    print(f"Error: {e}")
